"I favor microdata, but I would much prefer that microdata be dropped and (some version of) RDFa be in the main spec than that both exist indefinitely in parallel." - same reasoning about html5 and xhtml2 (a few years ago)?
microdata _is_ "some version of RDFa"
i just took rdfa and tweaked it until it didn't have the problems that made it inappropriate for the use cases that people asked for
(that's why it shared the same attribute names initially)
just like with wf2?
yeah, very similar to how WF2 was an attempt to make XForms work in HTML
Has there been much interest from the microformats community to start looking into defining formats utilising microdata?
Lachy: tantek worked on the Microdata vocabs, which are straight from microformats.
yeah, I meant other than those in the vocabs spec, which are just based on older microformats
You don't really have to do much of anything to use a microformat with the microdata syntax.  They already have the tree-structure defined.
that's good.
you have to do _some_ work to define it properly
but then that's work you'd have to do to define them properly for class=""/rel="" too
Is the plan to one day encourage people to phase out the older class-based hCard, in favour of the microdata version?
in fact, is there some problem being solved by mapping hCard into microdata?

"It seems you can access contentWindow, but trying to access contentWindow.document (for IE's "special" 404 pages) raises an "access denied" exception, so it's not exactly a restriction on document.cookie, but on document itself..."

Lachy: Yeah.  The class/rel syntax used by microformats atm requires custom parsing rules for every microformat, and still has a few notable failures (like the inability to nest vcards, frex).  Microdata gives you a single consistent parsing model to use, and solves nesting problems.
i expect the class/rel-based microformats will continue to exist -- they do work, and are deployed
Lachy: there are some notes here: http://microformats.org/wiki/html5
Hixie, yeah, I don't expect support will ever be dropped entirely.
hober, the wiki still mentions the <itemref> element, which was dropped.
Lachy: "yeah, I meant other than those in the vocabs spec, which are just based on older microformats" ... it's worth noting that new microformats are actually pretty rare.
so I wouldn't necessarily expect to see lots of new formats expressed in microdata in a short space of time.
webben, yeah, I'm aware of how frequently they create new formats
Lachy: wikis are for updating :)
hober, I would do it, but that would require me to remember what my microformats wiki username and password was

i meant ;)
Hixie: Mark Miller sure hates origin-based security, eh?
wonders if Mark will also object to postMessage()
mark probably doesn't hate origin-based security any more than i do, he's just less willing to keep extending it
personally i don't see an alternative, i don't think we can retrofit caps onto the web
I don't think it's a very good design, but I think it's more sensible to do the best we can with it than to try to fight it
since we can't entirely remove the concept of origin without badly breaking the web
indeed
i can certainly identify with his views; there's something to be said for not encouraging people to fight CSRF the way that Origin: suggests we fight it
Hixie: if you meant this message then I replied: <http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-web-security/2009Dec/0040.html>
but imho the alternatives are just too complicated given the way the web works
well, a secret token defense is potentially more sound, but you have to pretty much build it yourself, and you have to ensure that your secret tokens are actually unpredictable, not replayable, etc
and so the decision facing authors is not just origin-based csrf protection vs caps-based security, but between no security, weak security, and complicated security
and the latter is too expensive in practice for many authors
deploying both an Origin defense and a secret-token defense is better than either alone
indeed
and Origin is extremely cheap to add when you discover you forgot to protect a resource against CSRF, since it can be tacked on by an application firewall
but i expect he fears that people will pick "weak" over "complicated" if offered both
and that people will pick "complicated" over "none" if offered those choices only
i fear they'll pick "none", personally
which is why i'm ok with "weak"
well, at present "complicated" vs "none" is exactly the choice you get
indeed
and we see some people in each bucket
I'm not even sure of the scenarios where Origin fails as a CSRF defense
I'm pretty sure it works for the basic scenario of a Cookie-authenticated form, even if backed by nothing else
secret token CSRF defense has its own risks, precisely because of being complicated (in that it's easy to get it wrong)
origin's failures aren't as a csrf defense but as a generic defense -- i.e. the danger is that it'll be misused to do other things
so I don't even entirely agree with the framing, let alone the conclusion
I'm not sure what else you'd use it as a defense for (other than opening a hole to allow limited cross-site XHR, but that use is totally orthogonal to the use in the HTML5 spec)
I know his worry about Origin-for-CORS is about the possibility of mistakenly using Origin as the sole defense in cases where it is not sound to use it that way
right
not sure about Origin-as-CSRF-defense
well it's the same feature, effectively
so presumably if it can be misused, it can be misused, regardless of which spec mentions it
btw, the htmlwg process document says that "without prejudice" means the issue can't be reopened, not that it can't block LC, as far as I can tell
if CORS did not exist and you had only AnonXHR, then even if HTML5 still used it for CSRF defense there would be no way to abuse it without the same way
(though the latter is indeed implied by the former, obviously)
othermaciej: true
i guess
Hixie: "An issue that is closed without prejudice in this way can only be re-raised with approval of the Chairs."
right
so it's not that it can't be reopened, but I did forget to mention that approval of the chairs is needed
I corrected that technicality

Anyway, I recommend figure{display:table} figure>[caption]{display:table-caption;caption-side:bottom;} figure>[caption]:first-child{caption-side:top;}
And then a border and a light background.
pretty generic idea ;)

and tell me they aren't :focus tricks ;)
http://www.xanthir.com/etc/details

Okay, fine, I just came up with this.  I find it decent:
figure{
float: left;
border: 2px solid black;
-moz-border-radius: 8px;
-webkit-border-radius: 8px;
background: #c00;
margin: 1em;
padding: 2em 1em 1em;
position: relative;
figure > [caption] {
position: absolute;
width: 80%;
top: -20px;
left: -10px;
font-size: smaller;
border: 3px outset gray;
background: white;
color: black;
padding: 2px;
Use

oh man
getComputedStyle is fucked
Are you just realizing this?
for 'width' it returns the used value unless the element is not rendered (different from not in the DOM) in which case it returns the computed value
though not quite the computed value, since all non-percentages and non-keywords are normalized to pixels, which is not an absolute unit
gsnedders, not really, I realized it two years ago, which is why I postponed working on this
also, it's not consistent, e.g. for background-position you always get the computed value, normalized to pixels
so percentages for a rendered document do not get converted to pixels
the result of all this is http://dev.w3.org/csswg/cssom/#resolved-values
i now have to reverse engineer every CSS property...

My dilemna: Should I (a) point out how many things Shelley wants us to stop talking about, despite never 'quashing' conversation, (b) desperately argue that going this meta signals that we have nothing better to talk about, or (c) ignore the whole lot.
I'm thinking (c) is the best choice.  Meta breeds meta.
This is why dictatorship is a good idea for things like specs.
Otherwise people will talk forever about nothing.
TabAtkins: d) employ the "one post per day per thread" rule
jgraham: Sounds like a plan.
Sounds like the type of plan I would have come up with yesterday, in fact.
Happily I used my post to that thread already today
Well, I'm talking about the ubermeta "HTML6" thread that just started.  But I think I'll widen my rule to "per topic" rather than "per thread".  Meta is meta is meta.
employs the "zero post per day per thread" rule for threads that have too much indentation in m2
actually had to stop using an indented view of mail for that reason
indented threads are great because you can determine from the indentation pattern whether it's worth reading
I can't seem to find an answer to this in the HTML5 draft - how to determine the language of an element if xml:lang or lang are set, but to an invalid language code?
Do I treat this as lang="" i.e. language has been set to null?
Or do I treat it as a missing attribute and take the language from the parent element?
"If the resulting value is not a recognized language code, then it must be treated as an unknown language (as if the value was the empty string)."
Ah - well spotted - thanks.
Is there any point in "If your download does not start automatically, click here" pages?

It may just be an artefact at this point.  They all use an <iframe> loading the content, which should work everywhere.  At least it gives you something to look at while your browser decodes what the download is supposed to be.
I thought they're pointless, but opera.com does it too.
Well, pointless and/or attempts to expose you to more advertising.
Well, sometimes the connection itself fails
Then it's nice to have a link to click for a second try
You can just click whatever link would have gotten you to the "If your download does not start automatically" page.
Yeah, but that's less obvious to the user

AryehGregor: FWIW I think I almost entirely disagree with all the points that you made by email
But I am loathe to reply there because I don't think having a long drawn out discussion of this is helping anyone
I don't think that standards organisations should be compelled to produce a unique tehnology for each use case; that was the thinking that led to HTML being abandoned in the first place
And there are factual errors too
XHTML2 wasn't shut down until quite a while after HTML was resumed
I don't think it is possible to go from where RDFa is today and make it "good" by my criteria without making it "bad" from the point of view of the people who currently like it
This "one technology for one thing" issue also completely misses the fact that RDFa was made only for XHTML2
It's like saying don't make jet engines, we'll just put car engines on our planes, they do the same thing
the fact that multiple competing standards leads to uncertianty is bad but I expect it to go away over time once it becomes clear whether a technology has real traction
I don't think competition is a waste of resources if it leads to a better end result
jgraham: Agreed, but only up to the point that it's clear that one result is better.  At that point spending resources on the lesser branches is a waste.
and I think that given the choice today between using RDFa and using nothing, many people would chose to use nothing i.e. RDFa would not win by default
TabAtkins: We are far far away from that point
We're far away from knowing whether RDFa or Microdata is better for HTML?
I'd strongly disagree with that.
Since Microdata is "RDFa, but with better names and some tuneups based on actual use-cases".
And less horrible ideas
we're far away from having agreement in the HTML Working Group that it's clear that one technology is better (even though many individual WG members feel one or the other is clearly better)
True, agreement in the HTMLWG is still far off.
On the other hand, I'm somewhat pessimistic of either group actually shifting.
TabAtkins: I agree that it is better. But we're far from being able to show that it is better by being more successful
if Microdata had significant deployment success that outpaced RDFa, it would be easier to make the case
or likewise if RDFa had a lot more deployment success and use by data mining tools than it does now, while Microdata failed to get traction
I don't expect either of those things to happen in time for Last Call though
Besides, it seems all parites have acknowledged that RDFa 1.0 is lacking
So we can't even make a valid comparison until they hash out 1.1
is still of the opinion that nothing should happen before LC
I am interested in what they come out with for 1.1.  What I've heard of so far isn't addressing any of my concerns.
jgraham: I'd be fine with that.  It's the issue-raising people that are trying to force decisions now.  I'm on record as being fine with "wait until it's obvious".
Well, we can't reach LC until the issues are resolved...

Dashiva: I'm not sure what you mean
The color picker in Aion Online only reacted to clicks, you couldn't click and drag to the edge, so it was really hard to hit edge/corner values like pure black

Dashiva: but the OS X color picker dialog gives you a wide range of ways to pick colors, including by RGB clides, CMYK sliders, hue/saturation wheel plus luminosity slider, picking from an image, or selecting one of a number of predefined colors from a box of crayons
(also you can drag a color onto the color well control w/o even popping up a dialog)
